Comments_List: Introduction to music and sound synthesis.
Supercollider and how it can be used in audio synthesis. Audio synthesis more generally.
I gained a broad knowledge of sound synthesis techniques, used an arduino for the first time, and learned how to use SuperCollider to employ the techniques we learned.
The basics of sound synthesis techniques and programming in SuperCollider.

Strengths: very hands on, mostly decent introduction to sound synthesis.

Weaknesses: lectures are long and sometimes dry.
I really enjoyed the class and believe it is structured well on it's second go-around (I recognize the first time Scott taught this it was a bit messy.)

Many people might cite the lack of concrete structure as a weakness, but I didn't find it to be much of a problem. Professor Scott had some general goals and topics he wanted to hit, but he left room for the students to alter this to an extent based on what we found most interesting. Using SuperCollider was really awkward and difficult at first, but it got better as you learned it and we could always go to office hours or send an email if we needed help/clarification. As students have said in the past, there were times when the instructions/goals/expectations of an assignment were rather vague, but he tried to improve this as the semester went on with some degree of success.  I suppose at times, my not knowing whether or not my assignment was good enough encouraged me to spend more time improving it.
This course covers a broad range of topics in a short amount of time. It is great as a survey but doesn't go super in-depth to any topic.
If you're interested in the intersection of CS and music/sound, Scott is a fantastic person to learn from.

I would recommend this course to a student who is interested in the intersection of computer science and music. This was the reason I took the course despite very mixed course evaluations, and I found it to be really interesting.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in computer music or music in general with programming experience. The programming language used in the course is not fantastic from a computer science perspective but fits the applications very well, so don't take it as a generic CS course.
